Reviews.Title: Review by early owner and non professional
Reviews.Author: audiodude
Reviews.Content: I got the camers 3/15/13 and so far I am impressed. I am not a pro photographer but I do make software for a living. We make a product called iWatermark for Mac, Win, iPhone/iPad and Android so we quite a bit of experience with cameras. If you are interested our site is available with a search of Google (reviews don't allow links).This is my initial review. To get it out of the way the highlights are 50x zoom, Raw as option, video up to 440 fps (at very small rez). I've tried them all. They work as advertised and they are awesome features for a camera this inexpensive.Features* 16 megapixel BSI CMOS sensor. Photos look great.50x optical zoom lens (35mm equiv: 24-1200mm). Simply awesome.Great Optical image stabilisation3 inch 920k dot tilting LCD screen. Love the tilting LCD very handy when shooting over peoples heads. Also for shooting at kid or pet level.Hotshoe920k dot electronic viewfinder (EVF)Full 1080p HD video recording with stereo sound and at 60 fps.ISO 100-128001cm minimum focusing distanceHDR & panorama modesFull manual controls and RAW shooting10 fps continuous shooting full rez or down to 480fps (240 x 180 pixels) or 240fps (320 x 240 pixels) or 120fps (640 x 480 pixels).Many special effects.Switch on Time to Taking a Photo  2.55 secsShot to Shot without Flash  1.4 secsShot to Shot with Flash  2.8 secsI am still experimenting with the huge number of features in hardware and software of the camera and will report back when I get some time.It is the most powerful, versatile and inexpensive camera I've ever owned and I would recommend it highly. I have tried all the other super zoom cameras and this is the winner for me.PS To solve the squabble by two other reviewers the manual zoom is in the usual place by the shutter button on the right top and on the left side middle of the lens. It works well and smoothly with a bit of noise.

Reviews.Title: Not a DSLR but very, very nice
Reviews.Author: Tooncesmom
Reviews.Content: I was thrilled to be able to test and review the Fujufilm FinePix 16 Megapixel SL1000. It replaces a Canon Powershot G2 with 4 megapixels so is a huge step up for me. (And, to be admitted, a big learning curve, even though it's a "point and shoot" camera--at least for most of my photography.First of all, do download the online extended manual since the abbreviated one included with the camera is not completely accurate. One example: when charging the battery, the included manual states the charger light turns green. Not so. The orange LED turns off. I emailed Fujifilm Support to learn this tidbit. Also, if you're not familiar with the variety of shooting modes (Auto, Advanced, Scene Position, Motion Panorama, Shutter Priority AE, Aperture Priority AE, Manual and Custom) the included manual provides little detail. The downloadable 127-page extended manual is a necessity. I had mine printed on both sides and spiral bound since I will be referring to it constantly until I learn each procedure.The camera has many of the features of a DSLR, including a fantastic Fujinon 24 to 1200mm 50x zoom lens that is a combination of both spherical and ED lenses. With an aperture rating of f/2.9 - 6.5 (17 elements in 12 groups) you can count on great image quality. I've been shooting flowers in my garden and my jewelry creations using the macro in automatic mode and have been very pleased with the results. Even my hand-held shots are clear and detailed. A lever on the left-hand side controls the zoom and focus is automatic. Fujifilm offers 100x Intelligent Digital Zoom that brightens some of the darkest areas so my indoor shots are suitable for the high-quality images I need for my web page.The FinePix SL1000 comes equipped with a high-resolution electronic view finder that makes it easier to frame subjects (something I did not have with the Canon Powershot).I shoot mostly in JPEG (standard and fine) format but appreciate the ability to shoot in RAW. I'm still trying out the filters and the other shooting modes and will report back when I've fully evaluated these features. Also, I have not tested the HD video aspect.I like the size of the SL1000. Weight isn't a problem, but at just under one and a half pounds, it's a bit heavier than similar cameras due to the lens, and not something you could carry in your purse.The wide-angle LCD screen tilts to provide flexible viewing options for both high and low shooting positions, though for macro I prefer using the LCD screen in the flat position.The pluses far outweigh the negatives. Image noise has been mentioned ISO 100., but it hasn't been a problem for me. The lens cap detaches easily and is suspended by a cord so it won't be lost. Battery life is a problem, especially when using the zoom and/or shooting in automatic mode. Fujufilm's batteries are proprietary, but they are not expensive (under $20). I suggest keeping an extra battery or two on hand if you plan to shoot a lot of pictures. Charge time is under an hour with about 90 minutes for a first-time charge.Everything considered, I give the Fujifilm FinePix SL1000 very high marks. I love this camera.

Reviews.Title: Fabulous Photos - No Math
Reviews.Author: Kimberly Morris
Reviews.Content: I love taking photographs. My photos have won prizes at the Tennessee Valley Fair. (Whoo-hoo!)  Just once I'd like to say to someone, "My hobby is nature photography," and have that person reply, "Me, too. I love the intricacies found in a rose." But, no. They always reply,"Me, too. What shutter speed do you find most effective when photographing moving water in partial shade?" What's up with that? I'm not an engineer. If I wanted to spend an afternoon doing math, I'd balance my checkbook.  I am the artist; the camera is the scientist. My job is to notice how beautifully the shadow of an ancient oak tree falls on the side of an abandoned house. The camera's job is to capture that image digitally, without me having to tell it how. This camera is GREAT at that. Between the scene-recognition auto button and the choose-a-scene button (parties, beach, night scenes), this camera does everything I ask, and beautifully.The zoom is awesome. When I was taking pictures of the abandoned house, I couldn't step on the porch, because it was rotten. Still, I was able to get a close-up of the brass doorknob every bit as good as if I'd gone right up to it. Without a tripod. On an overcast day. It's the perfect camera for the person who's photography skills lie primarily with seeing great pictures. I see the picture; the camera takes the picture. I love this camera.

Reviews.Title: Massive zoom!
Reviews.Author: CyberNik
Reviews.Content: Being skeptical about buying a DSLR (due to the cost mainly) I decided to try out this bridge camera, and I must confess I was more than impressed. The main feature of course is the unbelievable 50x zoom, which is totally stunning, and will help you take photos you could never have imagined. Photo quality is quite good, although noise does make its way into certain iso settings, but it's not that obvious and you can easily correct this by "playing" with the settings(or lighting, if possible) . The camera focuses really quickly, though in macro mode if the light is low it may have a bit of a difficulty focusing. You can set the shutter and the aperture, or just switch to auto and let the camera decide what's best for it's shot. Generally, the photos in auto mode are very good, unless you want to tweak the settings for a specific shooting. You also get many creative options, like the toy camera effect and the cross screen, among others, which can give nice creative photos without the need of additional editing. Video quality is simply amazing, and luckily the camera keeps its focus(unlike previous Fujifilm models). There is also the option of raw saving, if you have the need for it. The lcd screen is crystal clear and it can tilt so it makes taking low or high photos a piece of cake.My only complaints:-the proximity sensor on the eyepiece is a bit tricky because it can be triggered by your body or hand and the lcd switches off to the eyepiece, which is kind of annoying ( you can select for the lcd to be always on and render the sensor inactive, which is exactly what I did).-the sound of focusing is apparent in videos ,like in previous Fujifilm's models.-Battery drains quickly especially if using the zoom, so you better have a couple of extra batteries at hand.For its features (especially the 50x zoom) and price, this is definitely a bargain. Due to the small amount of noise at certain iso settings I would give this camera 4 stars, but because of the price it is offered and the features it has, I chose to give it 5. Overall I'm very pleased with it and very happy that I bought it!

Reviews.Title: Good, but NOT good image quality
Reviews.Author: James P. MccArthy "FotoDad"
Reviews.Content: Tried out this camera for a week and returned it. My comparison is to the Canon SX40 and Nikon P510, of which have both been replaced by newer models, but with little difference (same sensors). The Fuji is a camera I wanted to love for it's easy to navigate menu, buttons in the right place for quick access/change, and decent build quality. As a long time photographer, my number one priority is good image quality (IQ). As much as I tried, I could not get this Fuji to give me sharp images. At all focal length, they appear soft..some very soft. I shot in good morning and evening light, a few in bright mid-day sun, and only a few true low light shot indoors with low lighting. Macro is decent, but nothing stellar. When compared to the Canon and Nikon, the Fuji just does not have the sharp, in focus, noise free images. The Canon's and Nikon's images are visibly much better, especially if viewing on a large monitor or flat screen HD tv. One big problem with the Fuji was at full zoom length, the focus (set to center)is almost impossible to lock..it constantly moves in/out of focus..very frustrating. If very good image quality is not your first requirement, then the Fuji is a contender. But for me, and after taking shots with the Canon and Nikon, I passed on this Fuji.

Reviews.Title: Canon sx 50 watch out
Reviews.Author: Todd
Reviews.Content: The Fuji SL 1000 is a great all around camera. The construction and features are user friendly and the quality of the pictures for the money, are second to none. I also own a Nicon D 7000.What I realy like about the Fuji is that is a lot lighter and with features that the camera offers makes it a great camera for travel.If I realy want the best pictures quality wise then I use my Nikon, but like I said for travel and wildlife photografy I don't see any other camera comming even close to this one once again for the price. I paid a little over $ 300 in amazon. The other camera that I considered very carefuly was the Canon sx 50 but the price difference was sustancial and I went with the Fuji.Battery life is a little bit short but for a little over $ 20 you can get the Wasaby replacement batteries (2) of them plus an extra charger.Once again I do not have any reservations recommending the Fuji SL 1000 as a secondary/Travel-wildlife camera

Reviews.Title: Overlooked and Under Rated: Best Deal in its Class, Easily
Reviews.Author: Randy Wakeman "Randy Wakeman"
Reviews.Content: Nothing competes with this camera at its current, stunning low price point of $250.The 28.5 oz. SL1000, uses the slightly smaller 1/2.33 sensor (compared to the Fujifilm HS50), yet is still a 24-1200mm 35mm equivalent camera. It also loses 25%-30% of the HS-50's its price as well. No other name-brand camera gets you to the massive 1200mm range for $260 or less, actually $250 as this is written. No one shoots at 1200mm all the time, or even most of the time for that matter. If you want the capability to do so, the SL1000 gets you there the most affordably. It offers a larger, 3 inch 920K dot tilting LCD, a 920K EVF as well: a better treatment than several more expensive cameras in this class. Consider the Sony DSC-HX300/B 20 MP Digital Camera with 50x Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 3-Inch LCD (Black) (about $400 at the time of this writing) that lacks RAW, and in general isn't as competent a camera, despite its comparatively high price.If the end use is standard prints, the internet, along with 8 x 10s from time to time, you'll be happy. Give it plenty of light, try to shoot at lower ISOs, you'll be more than happy. It is no secret that more pictures are taken every day with cellphones than with any other device. It is also no secret that sales of the smaller point and shoot cameras have plummeted, but long zoom cameras have been in demand. The SL1000 does everything that your smartphone cannot, and that's a good thing.There are a *lot* of choices out there, but not at $250. You can also spend $360 Sony DSC-HX50V/B 20.4MP Digital Camera with 3-Inch LCD Screen (Black) and more on pocket cameras, and more. You can spend a lot more on bridge-class cameras as well. The "Ultimate Compact Camera," according to some, is the Fujifilm X100S 16 MP Digital Camera with 2.8-Inch LCD (Silver). It is about $1300, though, with no optical zoom at all.Just two years ago, no bridge camera with a 1200mm zoom was even available. And, whether we like it or not, two years from now there are going to be several more options that some will call significant. That's why the SL1000 makes sense. Anyone would call it a generally very good camera if you didn't know what brand it was. For $250, though, it is a screamingly good, outstandingly superb camera. It isn't necessarily the best bridge camera, it isn't, but it is the best for the least dollars. If you are willing to spend more, yes . . . the SX-50 Canon, the Fuji FinePix HS50EXR are all quite worthy of your consideration, as are the Fuji X-S1 and the Panasonic FZ-200. For the money, though, at this price point . . . the SL1000 is a lot of bang for the buck.You'll probably want to drop twenty bucks for Pack Of 2 NP-85 Batteries And Charger Kit For FujiFilm FinePix SL240 SL260 SL280 SL300 SL305 SL1000 Digital Camera + More!! and Transcend 16GB Class 10 SDHC Flash Memory Card (TS16GSDHC10E) to get up and running. The 350 shot battery life is good, compared to the Nikon P520's 200 shots for example, but use outdoors in cooler weather nerfs that a bit, and even a small amount of video can run the battery down quickly.It is a far better-featured camera than expected, with the EVF and LCD quickly putting the more expensive Canon SX-50 and Panasonic FZ-70 units both to shame. Scoring 2,773 lines per picture height via Imatest, it is one of the sharpest len arrays ever put on a bridge camera. Nor can most bridge class cameras match the 1080p60 video capability of this economical powerhouse. It should surprise very few that this camera likes a lot of light, and if you are going to spend a lot of time at the 1000mm - 1200mm area, a good tripod is your friend. I won't suggest that this is my favorite wildlife / outdoors camera, the Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ200 12.1 MP Digital Camera with CMOS Sensor and 24x Optical Zoom - Black is, a far better camera for my purposes with commensurately higher price tag to go along with it.The SL1000 delivers solidly on its intended target: a huge zoom range for not huge dollars.Copyright 2013 by Randy Wakeman & Randy Wakeman Outdoors. Reviews.Title: Mid-level super zoom bridge camera.
Reviews.Author: D. Hentze
Reviews.Content: The Fujifilm FinePix SL1000 is Fuji's mid-level super zoom bridge camera. The S series is a notch below Fuji's high-end HS series of bridge cameras. Although it lacks some of the settings and features of the HS series, the SL1000 does have some features that are impressive. The main feature is its massive 50X zoom lens. Before I go any further though, I must point out that although this camera looks a little like a DSLR, it is not. It is a bridge camera with the same tiny sensor as you average pocket point and shoot camera. It is just housed in a DSLR style body, with some extra features and a massive zoom lens. Now that we got that out of the way, on to my review. Unboxing the Fuji SL1000, I noticed that it weighs slightly less and is slightly smaller than the Fuji HS50EXR super zoom. It weighs much less than my DSLR. In the box are the usual assortment of accessories. I was disappointed that there is no lens hood. First charge of the battery took about 90 minutes. The proprietary battery is charged in a proprietary external charger. The camera itself has average build quality and is almost entirely plastic. I was disappointed that even the tripod mount is plastic. The camera's ergonomics are very good, and everything is well laid out. No SD card is included, so make sure you have one. A fast "Class 10" speed card is recommended. The SL1000 menu system is very simple and easy to figure out. The camera has a variety of shooting modes including full automatic and "manual". There are also some built in filter effects which are pretty neat. I was disappointed there were no settings to adjust the camera's Noise Reduction like there is on the HS Series. The SL1000 does have RAW Mode which is a very good thing.I set out on a sunny day, and took over a hundred pictures under various conditions. I used several different modes and settings. I shot mostly in (P)Mode, and auto mode. I used Fine/JPEG Format, not RAW. Refresh time between shots was very fast. I noticed that when shooting in shady conditions, the camera would use an unnecessary high ISO. Sometimes 400 or higher. I turned off Auto-ISO and manually selected ISO 100 or 200 if needed. The 50X zoom lens performed well. It's incredible 24-1200mm range didn't disappoint. The 3" high resolution screen is very good. It's is clear and bright. It isn't an articulating screen though. It only slightly tilts, which I thought was kind of a weird design. While out, I also took several minutes of video to evaluate later. When I got home, I also shot a few dozen indoor pictures for testing purposes. I shot most of them in simple auto mode to see how the camera would handle low light without any help. After shooting 100+ pictures and several minutes of video, my battery still shows as full which tells me battery life is very good.When I finished my testing, I hooked the camera up to my PC and HD Monitor using the included USB cable. Thankfully, the cable is standard and not proprietary. Once downloaded, my results generally very good. Almost all my outdoor pictures came out excellent no matter what mode I used. Details were great. Colors were accurate. I didn't notice any optical aberrations, etc. The Fuji's Image Stabilization generally did a great job, but a steady hand is needed at the high end of the zoom.  The overall results were almost as good as my higher end HS50EXR, but not quite. I did notice a little image noise, especially when the camera went above 100 ISO. My indoor results were good too. Image noise wasn't bad up until ISO 400, and still acceptable at ISO 800. I have no doubt that with a little tweaking of the camera's settings, my results could be even better. My HD test video came out excellent too. It did not disappoint on my HD monitor.The Fujifilm FinePix SL1000 is not a DSLR, and it isn't perfect. It is a very good point and shoot camera with an incredible lens though. With a little trial and error, it produces very good results outdoors, and good results indoors as long as you keep the ISO as low as possible. I recommend it.Pros:Incredible 50x Wide Angle Zoom Lens.Electronic Viewfinder.Hot shoe.Good automatic modes.Manual controls.RAW Mode.Generally very good image quality indoors and out.Very good 1080i HD video quality.Fast focusing and refresh time between shots.Very good battery life.Good value.Cons:Average build quailty.Tiny 1/2.3-inch CMOS Image Sensor.Image noise noticeable above ISO 100.No noise reduction settings.No lens hood and mediocre accessories.Proprietary battery.

Reviews.Title: SLR features without SLR hassle and cost
Reviews.Author: W. L. Holder
Reviews.Content: There are many great reviews here already covering the main features of this camera, so I will keep my review of those features short.  The main benefit I see of this camera is that it provides many features of a SLR, but without the associated costs and hassles.I loved using my Cannon SLR.  Though due to its cost and having to drag around all the associated lenses, I rarely take it with me when I go somewhere I may want to take photos.  I seem to always take a small pocket camera with me now, as they have increased in performance massively over the past couple years.  The drawback to the  pocket cameras is that there is no hotshoe, the lenses dont zoom enough, or they just dont have the features I like about the SLR's.  This camera is the answer to that.  There are no lenses to change or drag around, yet you get excellent wide angle and zoom capability beyond what I have seen in any pocket camera.  There is a hotshoe in case you want to use a quality external flash, as the built in flash on pocket cameras are usually lacking.  In short, this is the perfect 'missing link' between a SLR and a pocket camera.The zoon is excellent, as is the wide angle setting.  With the image stabilizing, it takes quality photos even at higher zoom rates.  You will still need a rest or tripod for ultrazoom photos to be at their best though.Battery life seems to be typical of most cameras, nothing to exclaim or complain about there.  The weight is nice, enough to be stable in your hand but not enough to make your wrist or elbow tire if shooting for a long session.  The overall build quality seems good.If you are like me and prefer using SLR type camers, but dont want to risk taking an expensive SLR with you certain places, or dont want to invest in thousands of dollars worth of lenses, but dont want to revert to using a pocket camera for everything, this is a great option.

Reviews.Title: Advanced features that are easy to use
Reviews.Author: Juniorverse1
Reviews.Content: I'm enjoying how easy it is to take great photos with this camera.  Advanced users will be attracted to full shutter and aperture control.  More casual users will love the auto-scene analyzer and the fun special effects.Moving the mode dial to SR AUTO selects the auto-scene selector, which automatically detects the scene type and applies the optimal settings for the scene.  Examples include night landscapes and night portraits, backlit portraits, and daytime landscapes.  This camera does a good job of automatically detecting the scene and the resulting photos look great.The camera includes advanced filter effects that replaces the need for post-processing on your computer.  Effects include "toy camera", "miniature" that applies a tilt-shift effect, "pop color", "high-key", "soft focus", "cross screen" that creates star-like lines that radiate out from bright objects, and "partial color" effects that take black and white photos but keep a certain color, like blue or yellow, in its original form.  There are other post-processing tools like red eye reduction, cropping, and photo rotating.There are plenty of other presets that you would expect a point-and-shoot camera to have, like sport mode, night mode, fireworks, snow, flower close-ups, and more.  You can also take panoramic photos.  You can shoot movies in 1080i resolution.  The movies looks great, and there are easy editing functions for trimming or joining movies.The camera is not as small as many point-and-shoots, but it feels nice in your hands and the controls are well-placed.  Menus are easy to navigate and the camera does a great job of explaining the selected mode and how it operates.The lens extends significantly as you use the very powerful zoom.  When you zoom in very far, the camera still takes nice photos with the help of image stabilization.  The screen is bright and relatively easy to see in bright light.  There is also a digital display showing the typical camera settings as you look through the viewfinder.I definitely recommend this camera for anyone looking for a high-quality camera that is easy to use but also gives you plenty of control.

Reviews.Title: Better than the canon sx 50
Reviews.Author: Jimmy
Reviews.Content: I'm not a professional photographer but I am writing a review to tell you why I like the fujifilm sl 1000 better than the canon sx 50. They both have great 50x zoom but the fujifilm has more features. When using the canon it was weird not having features I was so used to having on my fujifilm. For example the canon lacks any kind of slow motion filming mode. The fujifilm has two different slow motion filming modes. The fujifilm screen is larger and much clearer. Also the veiwfinder is a lot clearer than the canon. The rubberized grip around the lens of the fujifilm makes it easier to hold and allows you to actually grip the lens like a DSLR. I won't get into the details of photo quality because the two camera are about equal in that area. Hopefully this helped you decide if you were between the two cameras. Remember not to buy a camera just because it says canon.

Reviews.Title: Amateur photographer
Reviews.Author: Spyndrilleum
Reviews.Content: I am a mother of 8. I hate paying ridiculous prices for school photos and to have our pictures taken in a studio. I wanted a camera that takes good quality pictures with out having to pay a ridiculous price for a professional camera. Especially since I don't really know what I am doing. I also wanted to pick up photography as a hobby. My sweetheart bought me this as a birthday present. I have yet to try any of the manual setting and have just been messing around with the camera in its factory preset mode. Now that I am a little more comfortable with it I am going to print the user manual for it.For now however I am very pleased with it!! The camera has taken really good shots of my kids on the trampoline and other action shots. They come out clear and beautiful. I have taken some pictures of my kids having them do poses in the yard all dressed up and in different natural lighting and the camera continues to impress me.I have uploaded some of the pictures I took using different zoom settings and different lighting. The spider one is taken in very low lighting with the stock flash. As you can see there is awesome detail. The dandelion is crystal clear and show in great detail. And the eagle is several mile away and the camera is fully zoomed and you can see the details in the wings. Again I am a point and shoot kind of person and when you talk ISO and Macro you might as well be speaking Greek. What I do know is that for an Amateur this camera is awesome! I would highly recommend it to anyone who wants good quality pictures with out the high price for a professional sitting. I think the pictures speak for themselves.

Reviews.Title: Well done, Fuji!!!
Reviews.Author: sashaineurope
Reviews.Content: Very pleased with this camera. I would like to make it clear that I am not a pro in photography, so those who expect an expert review may skip reading mine. I bought before this one Nikon COOLPIX S9200 16 MP CMOS Digital Camera with 18x Zoom NIKKOR ED Glass Lens and Full HD 1080p Video (Black) and had to return it since it was making blurry pictures and could not lock focus, also: when zoom used , the focus was missing at all. This Fuji camera is big (but light) and not so easy to carry everywhere or put it in your purse, but it is definitely worth carrying it. The pictures are crystal clear even when you use just automatic settings, or at night time(night pictures are a big issue with almost all cameras, but not with this - there are modes for beautiful night landscapes) . It is easy to lock a focus, also you don't need sturdy hand - quite shatterproof.(Make sure to hold the zooming lens underneath for extra support - check some youtube videos from fuji for instructions). The 50x zoom is amazing - you can use it as a binoculars and see exotic bird in the sky :). The close up photos of a flower or leaf are so crystal and detailed - beautiful. The 360 panoramic pictures - also! The videos - perfect.CONS: Many people complain that the lens cap has to be removed manually - for me this is a minor inconvenience (this is a huge lens and closing and opening automatically requests a lot of power).Also: the battery doesn't last a long time, but it is not expensive, I would buy a spare one to carry in the camera bag.I still have not tried all the modes and possibilities of this amazing camera. I have to say - Well done, Fuji!!!

Reviews.Title: If it had a manual focus mode and used AA batteries it would be practically perfect!
Reviews.Author: D. Jensen "snake man"
Reviews.Content: After the whole world had gone digital (except for me), I finally sold my extensive Olympus collection, consisting of 3 bodies and an arsenal of lenses, said goodbye to film, and bought my first digital camera - a Fuji SL7000. With a whopping 6-megapixel processor (pretty standard for the time), I used it to photograph my sister's wedding. The results were impressive. In 2008 I bought an Olympus UZ-570 (10-megapixels and a 20x zoom) for a trip to Africa, and I used that camera for six years until last month when I bought the Fuji SL1000.What can I say? The SL1000 packs a wallop in the zoom lens department! At 2 1/2 times the power of my Olympus "ultra zoom," the 50x zoom on the Fuji is a 1200mm equivalent in a DSLR system, eliminating a lot of weight to lug around and a lot of time and money saved by not having to buy expensive lenses and change them constantly. I did not want to return to the days of a 40-pound camera bag. The SL1000 and everything else I need fits neatly into a holster style case that I can wear on my hip.Photo quality is excellent, even at full zoom, with the camera compensating for shake. Video quality is equally good, and the stereo sound recording is amazing! The menu is intuitive, modes are logical and allow for a great deal of creativity whether you are a pro photographer or a newbie. I photograph snakes and other reptiles, and the SL1000's macro ability is phenomenal.I was disappointed that the SL1000 (and most of the new Fuji lineup) doesn't have a manual focus option. When I was in Africa, there were times when a lion was in tall grass and my Olympus would automatically focus on the grass, giving me a blurry lion. This was easily corrected by switching to manual focus mode. This is not possible with the Fuji, and could be problematic for anyone who spends time at the zoo photographing through glass, chain link, bars, etc., or who just prefers to be in total control by being able to focus on their own.Best features besides the lens include a hot shoe, an adjustable diopter (for folks who find it awkward to wear glasses while looking through a viewfinder), an adjustable screen for up and down (but not sideways) viewing, dual zoom controls, and a neat assortment of special effects, all packed into a solid, lightweight, compact camera.One of my main criteria for choosing digital cameras in the past was the ability to use AA batteries which are inexpensive and available everywhere. Battery type was the main reason for choosing the SL7000 and the UZ570. I compromised with this camera because I wanted the zoom, and I wish the technicians at Fuji would try to be more consistent in making all of their cameras AA compatible. Right now it's about half and half. (Are you listening, Fuji?) Proprietary batteries are a pain in the butt! They are expensive, require a charger, and are difficult to charge away from home, especially in foreign countries.Overall, this is an excellent camera choice for anyone who wants a simple-to-use camera that yields excellent results.

Reviews.Title: Great family camera
Reviews.Author: Kat
Reviews.Content: Since I loved my Fuji Finepix E550 that finally died this year after almost 8 years of service, I knew I would go back to Fuji for my next camera. My husband has always wanted a great zoom for when we go hiking so that was first on our list of must haves for the new camera. After much deliberation, research, and discussion, we decided to go with the SL1000. And after a week, I am so glad we did. This camera is great for a family with young children who don't stop moving!Our previous camera was blurry inside and during playtime outside but this one is fabulous! The many modes are great for all the different situations you find yourself in with kids. Pictures that were once blurry in the living room at night are now clear and well lit. Running pictures are clear. To be honest, it did take a couple of days of playing with different settings to determine what mode is best for what but I think that is true for any camera. The zoom is great! The stabilization works very well. The filters are fun and give you some room to be artistic if you so choose. The high speed video is a lot of fun. My six year old finds it entertaining to make slow motion videos of toys falling. The HD video itself is wonderful and a lot better than the previous camera.I would recommend buying more batteries. The one that comes with it does last quite a while and it charges in about 2 hours but it is well worth it to have extras. Also, the strap that comes with it is not comfortable around the neck. Kind of scratchy. I would recommend getting something different.Updated 11/24/13: This camera has now gone a trip with us to Colorado and some serious hiking. The pictures were fantastic and the video is equally as great. The zoom was so great out there that we got many pictures we would have never gotten without it. It also got used at work for our annual party which was in low bad lighting and it performed wonderfully. Still love this camera!

Reviews.Title: Good all in one camera
Reviews.Author: Amy Willingham
Reviews.Content: I currently own Sony Cyber-shot DSC-HX200V which I LOVE and take on all of my travels. But the price difference between my Sony and this Fujifilm is about $150 which makes the Fujifilm more affordable for people looking for an all in one camera.Pros:*Very easy to navigate on screen- able to change how you take pictures and speeds*Gives you almost all the functions of SLR in one complete camera without having to worry about changing lenses.*Has very quick focus and super fast shutter speeds. I shot some pics of the boys playing basketball and this camera is great at capturing them mid-air or at other times when they are running back and forth. A common problem with Non-DSLR cameras is that they can't capture objects moving fast enough or they do but them come in really blurry. With my Sony, I am able to capture people in mid-air but when they are running back and forth it can become a challenge to get a clear picture. I say with my Sony 1 in 4 will be perfectly clear but with this Fujifilm 3 in 4 come in clear.*Super zoom function with clear focus- My Sony can only do 30x zoom while this Fujifilm can do 50x!*Easy to grab photos from camera to import into your computerCons:*For a non-DSLR this camera is a bit heavy and bulky. When I compare the weight and size with my Sony this camera is both bigger and heavier. For a person looking for a camera without having to change lenses the weight and size shouldn't be an issue. But for others who are looking for a slimmer non-DSLR camera that they can throw into a backpack and not worry about extra weight, this camera is not the right one for you.*Doesn't have high quality low light/night shot ability. My main factor in purchasing my Sony was how frustrating my old point and shoot would take museum pics and night shots. Even though this Fujifilm says it works well for low light/night shots I am personally not impressed by it. If one of your main buying reasons for this camera is low light shots (such as museums,concerts, and late night parties)I have to tell you to look somewhere else. The pictures still come in very dark and blurry if your object is in motion. Now if I where to take the same pics with my Sony... as my hubby says "Hey look your camera just made these night pics into day pics!"Overall for the price and what this camera can do I think it's a great value(unless you wanted a camera for low light and night shots) and has everything all in one camera. The zoom function is amazing and even though my Sony can go up to 30x.. with 50x the zoom I can just imagine all the shots I could have taken of Our Lady Liberty while I was on the Staten Island Ferry. And trust me my Sony got some AMAZING shots of her! So instead of buying a true DSLR that can cost you over $1,000 and you will have to carry multiple lenses, I suggest paying 1/4 the cost and investing in this Fujifilm. If you love this camera abilities and just wished it could provide good quality low light and night shots, I have to suggest Sony Cyber-shot DSC-HX200V.

Reviews.Title: Easy to use!
Reviews.Author: Ken N
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera as a more light-weight option when traveling. We just returned from two weeks in Nepal where we trekked through the foothills of the Himalaya and then ventured down to Chitwan National Park for an elephant safari through the jungle. The camera was very portable and easy to use and the pictures I took, even on the AUTO mode, were outstanding. I am still amazed by the camera's performance. I would highly recommend this camera for a more convenient option when on rigorous trips.

Reviews.Title: Initially great camera, BUT (see followup review)
Reviews.Author: Denny
Reviews.Content: I bought this for a trip to Washington, DC. It worked great. Easy to use if you've had an SLR camera before. The telephoto lens did a great job at it's max setting while being held by hand. Haven't had a chance to check out other features, yet.Followup review...I purchased this camera roughly 6 months ago because it had so many great reviews, and at first, I thought it worked very well. I bought it for ease of use, however I'm starting to be a little disappointed.1.  If I didn't use the camera for a couple of weeks, it would not turn on. I thought it was the battery, so I charged it (but thought this was funny because the battery should last a little longer without being used). It didn't take long to charge which was unusual, but it seemed to work fine after that. I would just have to remember to check the charge a day before I planned on using it, but was worried that when one of those special pictures came up that it wouldn't work. AND, this is just what happened. Only this time, when the camera wouldn't turn on, I pulled the battery out and put it back in and it worked and showed fully charged. I've charged the battery several times now. I just went to see if it would turn on and it wouldn't. I put it in the charger and it wouldn't charge. I'm assuming a bad battery (it should have lasted longer than this).2.  Preview button. I pressed the Preview Button to look at some of my pictures, but at times it would say that the picture was corrupted, so I lost the picture. It would almost freeze searching for the picture. Not sure if that was the card or not, but shouldn't have been.3. This Christmas I used the camera at our family Christmas. Many pictures turned out blurry when a subject barely moved. It's always taken descent pictures in low light, but not that night. I had to turn the flash on to get better pictures, but the lighting was adequate for clear pictures. Sometimes it works right, sometimes it doesn't.I'm a little disappointed that I have to spend so much time trying to get this camera to do what I want it to do and I am no novice when it comes to cameras. I've had other SLR cameras before this one.I'm going to get in touch with Fuji to see what they will do.

Reviews.Title: SlL1000 Buy It
Reviews.Author: Pete
Reviews.Content: After reading many reviews , watching you tube videos and several visits to Best Buy to compare Sony, Nikon, Canon, and Fuji I ordered the Fuji SL1000 from Amazon. No one had the SL 1000 in stock so I looked at the S8200 from Fuji for comparison purposes.  Why the SL1000?  First of all the battery is rechargeable, has a viewfinder along with the LCD screen that tilts, has a 50X optical and 100X digital zoom and can shoot in Raw not that I will use it much..  The SL 1000 is so close to price of the S8200 and  S8400 why settle for less. The closest Nikon and Canon cameras with viewfinders were at least $100 dollars more. I was  concerned about picture quality but I was convinced on Amazon by the reviews by the semi pro photographers to buy this camera as all of those reviews were positive and had 4 or 5 stars under photo quality. Although I have only had the camera for two days I know I made the right choice.  I took the camera to the ocean (15 degrees below zero wind chill factor) and got some great pictures.  I have taken both good and bad pictures but the  bad ones were my fault. I have experimented with the different settings and shooting modes and still have much to learn. I have the camera picture quality set to Fine and 4.3. The memory card will hold less pictures but the quality is higher with better resolution. I am using a High Performance SDHC Pixtor  SanDisk Class10 Memory Card. I have taken some  good pictures on auto mode but got even better results with experimenting with the different settings. If you want to take time to really learn how to use this camera it is IMHO the best camera with the  most features at the best price. A friend of mine who is a semi pro photographer stopped by the house today and saw the  camera.  She picked  the camera up and was surprised at how little it weighed and used the 50X  optical zoom and said "that is Sick", I guess that means she was impressed. There are simpler cameras out there and the SL 1000 can be used on the auto modes to get good pictures but if you want to learn more about photography and become a better photographer this is the camera to buy unless of course you want  full DSLR and many lenses.  At $249 on Amazon I felt I could not go wrong and at that price I bought the 4 year protection plan at  $42.00 which includes accidental damage with some exceptions.  The price for the camera and protection plan is less than most cameras in this class at most stores.  I am looking forward to learning how to get the best results from my camera and am very happy with my purchase. I hope this review is helpful to some of you. Good luck with your decisions.

Reviews.Title: Take great photos without any photography knowledge.  Comparison to S4500,  choose cost based on your photography needs.
Reviews.Author: Two kids mom "scienceteachermom"
Reviews.Content: We already owned a FinePIX S4500 and I will compare the SL1000 to this camera.  Currently the S4500 is about half the price of the SL1000. We love both of them, but the comparison below may help you make a choice between the cost/benefits for both cameras.These cameras are excellent choices for those who want more than a little point and shoot but less than a full fledge SLR.  They both offer the ability for the total photo novice to take excellent photos and as you learn more for you to take more control over the shots.  The size and weight are much lower than an SLR and the options much greater than a point and shoot.  If you are going to be taking photos of birthday parties, soccer games and vacation photos the lower end S4500 will serve you quite well, you can even move up to more complex photography by taking over some of the control from the camera as you learn.  If you want to move up to images you can really edit, higher optical zoom,  (want to be able to do extreme close ups) ,the ability to have different outputs,  to be able to add a fancier flash (perhaps use one you already have for an SLR) or video extreme close ups then you should chose the higher end SL1000.  You do need to manage battery use more with the SL1000, since it uses a rechargeable battery rather than standard AA.  For a more detailed comparison and more information continue reading.Weight and Size: The S4500 weighs about 19 oz (540g) with the AA batteries and the memory card) and the SL1000 about 23 oz (650g).  This would not seem like a lot, but held in your hand it does make the difference.  The longer optical zoom (50X on the SL1000 vs 30X on the S4500) means that the SL1000 is front heavy and it does feel heavier when you are holding it.  It is also physically larger although not a huge amount.  Carrying it in the case makes little difference.Image:The S4500 is 14 pixals while the SL1000 is 16.2.  When printing your average photos you will probably not notice the difference, we cannot tell which photos were from which camera.The S4500 has a focal Length of 24-720mm and the SL1000 from 24 to 1200mm (this is a big difference, you can take photos from MUCH farther away with the SL1000).  Full aperture is F3.1 (wide) to F5.9 (telephoto) on the S4500  and F2.9-6.5 on the SL1000.  The SL1000 can go up to the equivalent of ISO 12800 while the S4500 goes up to 6400, another big difference, meaning that the SL1000 can handle lower light levels.  Fuji is a leader here,  they get lower noise in high ISO shots without blurring detail (algorithms will decrease the image detail in some other camera brands).  There is some argument about how film ISO translates to digital ISO, but for comparison purposes across the same brand the SL1000 is much better here.JPEG  (Stills) and AVI (movies) are the only file outputs on the S4500 while the SL1000 can do JPEG, RAW (RAF format) and even MPO (Which is 3D) as well,  the movie output is in MOV form not AVI.The S4500 actually has more shooting modes (Zoom Bracketing, Natural Light, Natural Light & with Flash, Portrait, Baby, Smile, Landscape, Sport, Night, Night (Tripod), Fireworks, Sunset, Snow, Beach, Party, Flower, Text) than the SL100 which has (Portrait, Landscape, Sport, Night, Night (Tripod), Fireworks, Sunset, Snow, Beach, Party, Flower, Text).  They both have a Panorama mode as well.  The modes are actually pretty amazing, point the camera at a person and it knows the difference between that and a flower.The zoom on the S4500 is at the front while the SL1000 has both front zoom and a button on the side of the lens for zooming.  There is NO manual zoom on either, which those who previously use SLRs will find annoying.Both have a build in flash, but the SL1000 has a shoe (a place you can put a fancier flash, like for an SLR)Both have SR AUTO, Instant zoom, Face Detection, Auto red-eye removal, Framing guideline, blink detection, Frame No. memory, Histogram display, motion panorama, Face recognition, Date stamp and the SL1000 adds an advanced mode, zoom bracketing and a framing guideline.  The blink detection can be amusing, we have been told that the camera detected a blink in a tree....Video:The S4500 video quality is lower,  1280X270 (mono sound)  vs 1920X1080 (stereo sound).  This is noticeable when playing back on a TV both in image and sound quality.  However, the lower quality is perfectly acceptable, better than my Flip video and in both cameras you CAN use the optical zoom when recording video on both cameras which is really neat.Power:The S4500 uses AA batteries, and I would suggest the lithium ones.  In fact, with the lithium batteries the S4500 takes noticeably more photos that the SL1000 with its rechargeable NP85.  You need to buy another NP85 (two are less than 20 bucks on Amazon currently) so you can charge one while using the other.  The fact that you can buy AA anywhere makes the S4500 more versatile here.LCD:The LCD on the SL100 can fold out, should you want to hold the camera at a weird angle to take a photo and still see what you are doing.  This is nice, but adds to the cost.Summary:Either of these camera is an excellent choice taking your general photographs to another level beyond point and shoot but without the expense and weight of an SLR.  If you want to really get into photography or higher quality video is important to you, choose the higher end camera.  If you are not sure, you just want to take great photos without much effort,  go for the lower end,  you can still have some control as you learn to take better photos and if you decide later you need something fancier, cameras will have probably improved even more in the meanwhile.

Reviews.Title: Better than my sx40 canon
Reviews.Author: Wen "wmrss"
Reviews.Content: I usually don't write reviews, but decided this is worth writing. I am usually a canon person but have always been open to other brands, I must say I like this Fujifilm sl1000 much better then the canon sx40. The zoom is great have took great pics handheld at full 50 times zoom.Lots of features on this camera. Have owned this for 30 days and have taken several 100 pics with all coming out clear.

Reviews.Title: Great camera, but it is missing one thing.
Reviews.Author: P. Oberlander
Reviews.Content: The zoom is really great.The feature set is robust.  I love that it has aperture and shutter priority modes.It has a hot shoe for external flash, which you will need if you use the zoom in low light (on any super zoom).My only problem is that it has no manual focus.  When you are trying to shoot distant objects against a flat background (like the full moon or (believe it or not, I got a picture of this) the crescent of Venus, getting the camera to focus isn't easy.  If you could set the focus to infinity manually, it would be a perfect 5 star.

Reviews.Title: Good Camera
Reviews.Author: MWA
Reviews.Content: I spent a lot of time researching various "cross over" cameras: 16 MP or better, zoom telephoto. Price was definitely a consideration. All things considered, this was a good choice. The telephoto is better than I could have asked for. The images are bright and crisp when viewed on my computer screen and 46" HDTV. I have used it more for outdoor photography than indoors, I need to practice more on the indoor settings. There are a lot of setting possibilities, some of which I will probably never use, but you never know...I've shot a little video and it was fine for me, but I'm not that into video.A few notes:-Order a second battery, you'll be glad you did.-Use a tripod for distant/lowlight telephoto shots.-I wish I could get a haze filter that would somehow fit the lens, I hate to touch a camera lens, even with microfiber, and a haze filter offers good protection from inadvertent finger smudges, splashes, etc. No matter who you are, things happen!-the case recommended on the Amazon site works well. It holds the camera snugly, and has room for the USB cable, extra battery, microfiber cloth, maybe one or two other small items.

Reviews.Title: Good buy
Reviews.Author: The Woodlander "Wally"
Reviews.Content: I have very little to complain about with this camera. Almost all of my pictures come out very clear. The only flaw is not it's fault; it's a fault of all non-DSLR cameras. It recharges slowly between shots, so that you can't take rapid fire shots of moving events. I bought this as a supplement to my Nikon D3200 because we're going on a cruise in May and it's cumbersome to be carrying a large bag for lenses, and for changing lenses (Nikon) itself when you don't have all the time to do so. The Fujifilm FinePix SL 1000 solves that problem. But use this only for non-rapid fire shot requirements. Otherwise, I'll use my Nikon. So each one has its advantages and disadvantages. The ideal would be for a DSLR to have a fixed lens of from 24-1200mm, like my Fuji. Is this even possible (for you professionals out there!)?

Reviews.Title: Great
Reviews.Author: Pranab N. Jha
Reviews.Content: Its my first high end (for me) camera. I took some pics recently in the auto mode and they came out great. Even in low light and setting sun, the pics were very clear. There are lot of modes you can play with. I myself have yet to experiment with all of them, but my initial feel is that the camera is very good for its value. The zoom is excellent, best feature I think.

Reviews.Title: Great camera to grow with
Reviews.Author: Sue Sutton
Reviews.Content: I first saw this camera featured on HSN and fell in love with it on site.  Then when I received it as a Christmas present, I was so excited.  It has so many precalculated settings to help even the beginner take the most amazing pictures.  I used the SNOW setting just yesterday to capture the beauty of the last snow storm.  Beyond the presets, other features of the camera that help with ease of use are the big tilting screen to help get those difficult angled shots, the automatic eye sight conversion from the screen sight.  The weight of the camera is well balanced with the deep grip.  The zoom is accessible from the front of the shutter button and also on the left side of the camera lens.Overall, I love, love, love this camera.

Reviews.Title: so so bridge camera
Reviews.Author: Adam
Reviews.Content: The idea of this superzoom camera is appealing but so far the images are grainy.  Further, I think I would prefer to manually zoom rather than electronically zoom.  Might want to upgrade to the the HS50exr.

Reviews.Title: Incredible Camera and Easy to Use
Reviews.Author: Darena Shopz "darenashopzatoutlookdotcom"
Reviews.Content: I'm not a professional photographer, just a mom that likes to take a lot of pictures. I like cameras to be automatic. I don't know what to adjust, how much lighting I need, etc. I had used point and shoot digital cameras for several years and was never satisfied with the results. They were OK but the color quality is only so-so. For about a year or so I have been just using my iPhone for a camera, mainly just because I have it with me. Unless I am outside, the color and lighting is terrible on it and if anyone moves at all, it's blurry. I have been wanting a better camera.I have been using the Fujifilm Fine Pix SL1000 and am thrilled with it! It provides such great quality pictures and easy to use.I have used it in all sorts of situations and it has provided top quality pictures in them all. We shot pictures of the super moon and used the zoom to get some super close photos of the moon. We went on a cave hike and took it with us and all the pictures turned out great. It was completely dark except for very low lighting from some lights and the camera knew exactly what to do to make the pictures look great. I took them on the SR AUTO mode which selects optimum camera settings for certain modes. We have also used it for just everyday shots, inside and outside and they have all turned out excellent. All the colors seem true to life and not red like my last camera and my iPhone both take.The hardest part about using the camera for me was trying to put that stinking strap on. My husband put it on without much trouble though.The camera comes with the strap which is really nice and the USB cable so you can hook it up to your computer. This camera has a rechargeable battery so it also comes with that and the battery charger and plug adapter. You'll also get the lens cap and string to attach it and a basic owner's manual. Included is a  CD which has the complete owner's manual in PDF on it and a picture program.I am really pleased with this camera, it's all I could ask for in a camera. It's pretty heavy and large but it still fits in my hand well and wasn't uncomfortable to lug around all day while we hiked since it has the nice, large strap.I highly recommend it!

Reviews.Title: Its just Okay
Reviews.Author: R Hogan
Reviews.Content: Well I was hoping for a large Zoom which this camera has without the noise,Sadly Fuji did not put enough thought into this model to reduce the noise even at 100 iso. So I sent it back and maybe next time they will get it right,Had some nice features but noise to me is a deal killer.

Reviews.Title: I love this
Reviews.Author: Half Fast Farmer
Reviews.Content: I am not a great photographer. I have zero training. I have never taken great pictures or really enjoyed taking them.So I loved this camera. Suddenly, I can take decent pictures. Ansel Adam's legacy is still safe but I can take pictures that are beautiful to me. That has been so fun. I have a ranch in the Rocky Mountains. We have some amazing wildlife around but they are always too far away and moving too fast to take good pictures. But with this camera I have gotten some amazing shots of elk and wolves that were so far away I could barely see them. The camera takes care of the distance and movement easily and quickly enough to catch the really great moments.I have actually taken the camera off "auto" and tried some different settings. I have been able to work with them and get some fun shots. I have looked a couple things up but mostly it is really easy to figure out how to use this camera.The camera is heavier than I expected. All of the components work smoothly and feel sturdy. To remove the battery cover you have to slide a button down while pushing the battery cover to the side. It is a little awkward. The battery lasts for the weekend.I could not be happier with this camera. I would recommend it to anyone.

Reviews.Title: Everything I was looking for
Reviews.Author: Adam
Reviews.Content: My wife and I have never heard any good or bad about Fujifilm so I was hesitant to by this camera. I took a gamble and it paid off. Its got all the gadgets a geek like me loves and the simplicity and speed my wife enjoys. SUPER zoom is awesome and it takes great shots. I recommend a monopod just in case you have slightly shaky hands like me for those relay close up zoom shots. Everything on this camera works great and better then I expected. The only down side is that the battery does not last as long as my under water camera, but that's to be expected with something that multitasks like this. It last a couple of hours but I recommend a second battery if you plan on taking it the whole day. Other then that, AWSOME. And the price cannot be beat......... ;)

Reviews.Title: love it
Reviews.Author: gary doberstein
Reviews.Content: this camera is awesome it takes awesome pics... the zoom is just wow ive been using fuji cameras for years and this is deff the best one yet  ty

Reviews.Title: Very good camera for many
Reviews.Author: Seaweid
Reviews.Content: I got this just before Christmas to capture all the fun stuff of the season.  Works great and is just what I wanted at a great price.  In fact the price dropped a few days after I got it and I called Amazon and they gave me a credit!  That's why I like buying from them.  They stand their policies without B.S. !I have 2 older SLR units (film) but it is getting so difficult to use these anymore, and costly.  Electronics has indeed taken over and for the better as a general note.  The 50X OPTICAL zoom is just right for most situations and very easy and FAST to shoot with so you don't miss the action.  This however is NOT a $1200 camera like some have tried to state or compare. It is however one of the best for those that want an upgraded unit, easy to use/understand, and doesn't set you back a house and car payment! Ha!  I believe you will enjoy this unit at many different levels and has many cool extra features that are always a plus to use.  The number one reason, out of many I purchased this is for FAST on the go shots that I could zoom in quickly and not have to deal with changing lens types...  what a pain when you just don't have the time or want to carry the big bags.  That's why some professionals have two or three cameras around their neck - FAST SHOOTING.  But then most of them are getting paid for it!So...  go for it if you what a very good upgrade that has many nice extras, to a snap n shoot camera that really brings home quality lasting pictures forever!  I have already used the tilt back screen to shoot shots in crowds as I am not real tall, and got the shots of "Santa" in arriving.  Happy picture taking!ps...  Do Not go cheap on the memory card!  This camera is a high-end fast shooting and must have a very fast grade card.  Most brands are fine as long as they are coded "HCI or (10) speed. SD cards come in many speeds along with the size or amount they can hold. You will kick yourself and blame the camera if you use less, like a no. 4 speed, good for low end stuff.  They just are not built to record fast data that your new camera can produce.  Have fun!

Reviews.Title: Definitely a winner in my book
Reviews.Author: Joshua Ramirez Wharwood
Reviews.Content: I'm coming into this previously owning a Fujifilm FinePix S4000 which unfortunately died after a good run. You can tag me as the type that loves having a good lens and the ability to do some SLR-like tweaking without the SLR premium price.With that said, PROS:- You really have to see the 50x zoom this thing boasts about to believe it. Like, WOW- There is a hot shoe in addition to a pop-up flash- It handles RAW images- Image quality is not as stellar as an SLR, but as long as you keep the ISO low, you'll get some images with good exposure, sharpness and color-The build quality is top-notchCONS:- The power switch is a bit wonky at times. It doesn't respond until after a firm, emphasized slide- The eye sensor is very sensitive. Normally I just force it to remain on either the LCD or the EVF via the EVF/LCD button- For some, the price may be a bit off-putting (the alternatives can go for as little as half the price of this one), but the amazing zoom and the feature offerings are more than worth itOut of all the cameras I've played with here and there, so far this one feels like the most versatile; whether you're a pro looking for an array of photography styles, or someone like me who's still learning the intricate stuff, it will meet your demands and then some. Truly 4.5 out of 5 for me, but because Amazon loves integers so much, 4 stars.

Reviews.Title: Find out what you want before buying a camera!
Reviews.Author: AG
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera at a great price! You need to know what you want first, before buying a camera.  What do you want it for?  where are you planning to use it the most, indoor or outdoor?  How much do you want to spend?  Is size important? etc...Here's my take:I have never done any kind of photography, other than casual phone or point and shoot; but, this year I felt like getting a camera that would make me enjoy taking pictures!  I couldn't be happier: now, I never leave home without it; every day is a 'shooting' opportunity.  Please read all the technical details about this camera, so you can be informed of what you're getting.  I can only write about the practical shooting enjoyment that I'm getting out of this:1. Great feel on the hand, secure, solid, and balanced weight2. Easy to use, and learn to navigate3. Easy to transfer pics to computer, using the SD card or USB cable4. Great shooting range, from close up distance(macro) to out of sight distances(over a mile!)5. Fairly good quality; the better you get with camera, the better the pictures get(take your time to learn to use all its features!)6. Performs great under low light(find out best setting for best results!) as well as outdoor sunny days7. The zoom really works, and makes this camera all worthy!This camera is exactly what I wanted; It's a little bulky, but very comfortable on the hand.  I would give it a 5 stars if I was better at taking pics; the more I learn, the more the rating increases.  I highly recommend it...

Reviews.Title: Beat Similar DSLR Camera!
Reviews.Author: Claudia V. Mcdowell "Claudia Vera"
Reviews.Content: Please listen to this review. I got the camera as a present  for christmas. Although amazon had many christmas orders mine came in 1 week, past christmas but still ontime. When i turned on the camera i was not impressed. The screen looked grainy and pixelated! I was so disappointed and was wondering if i should return it. I then stRted exploring the camera. I had already watched "the fuji guys" videos on youtube teaching how to use it. It hepled so much! As i started exploring it i found over 10 filters or shooting options! The panormama is also amazingly great and the macro quality was absolutely AMAZING. I got the camera for the amazing FULL HD camera quality. I wanst disappointed. The video is so clear and amazing i can even see it perfectly clear on my new 50" tv! There are also many other features for advanced camera people. My favorite was the amazing zoom that wasnt pixelated even after zooming in ALL the way! The viewfinder is also very cool because it has any eye sensor so the lcd turns on and off if you near the viewfinder! This camera is ABSOLUTELY AMAZING and worth the money!!!

Reviews.Title: Great All Purpose Camera
Reviews.Author: E. Clark
Reviews.Content: This camera is very easy to use, right out of the box.  The SR Auto setting allows a very wide range of focus from extreme zoom to extreme macro, from bright light to almost no light.  Being able to tilt the viewing screen is very helpful.  I prefer to use the viewfinder rather than the screen, so I was a bit disconcerted for a few seconds when I brought it to my eye, as the camera automatically goes from the screen to the eyepiece.  That was very easy to adjust to.Since the extreme zoom also magnifies motion, I was concerned about being able to hand hold.  The shutter speed and image stabilization make it possible to brace against something solid and get the distance shot without a tripod.I have an older professional level DSLR with changeable lenses, which is a very good camera, but also very heavy.  This Fuji is much lighter weight and easier to take along.This camera has many of the features of a DSLR, and for the price it is an excellent choice.

Reviews.Title: My new all in one camera - Good quality pics with ultra zoom
Reviews.Author: XNOR
Reviews.Content: I have a Canon T2i SLR camera with 3 lenses (18-55mm, 50mm fixed, 75-250mm) and when I want to travel - I have to carry the huge camera, the lenses and keep switching them to take good quality pictures.Now with the Fujifilm finepix I do not have to do that - I just need to carry one camera which covers more zoom than all my lenses put together.What is good about this camera ?  - Ultra zoom with focus length as low as 1 cm - even my Canon T2i cannot match  - Quick focus and fast shutter speeds for action scenes - shot some birds moving and was capture very well even when the light was not that bright  - Full SLR functions to adjust aperture, shutter speed, ISO to shoot the images your wayWhat is not good about the camera ?  - As much as bulky as an SLR - but atleast you do not have to carry that many lenses  - I really really miss my canon 50mm fixed focal length lens for portrait images : nothing in this camera matches that lens :)  - Ultrazoom without a tripod is pretty usesless since even a small shake will distort the image - that is with any other cameraOverall - it is a better alternative to SLR - not only does it work out better in terms of price, but also more convenient to carry and play around with.~Update :  After using it for the last couple of months - I tend to go back to my DSLR or my point and shoot primarily because of indoor picture quality - which are not really up to the mark. Hence I reduced the rating from 4* to  3*

Reviews.Title: Best in class features offset by image noise issues
Reviews.Author: Rowan Wing
Reviews.Content: I really wanted to like this product. Hi-res EVF and Screen, dual zoom levers, good build quality and grip on zoom barrel, high speed video etc.Why did this not work for me?Best in class features combined with high noise even at low iso. This has to be compared with other very small sensor megazoom cameras, which is what I am doing here. There is no point comparing to APS-C sensor cameras (compact mirrorless or DSLR), apples and oranges.- Image quality plagued by noise at 400 or even 200 iso. A lot of reviews discuss this. Compared to the competition, image noise is much higher even at low ISO. That is a big trade off even with a much lower price tag.- Zooming is not that fast compared to sony or canon (hx300/sx50) although released after- Manual focus is not availableI am still looking for the ultimate bridge camera in 2014. I am waiting to get my hands on a Sony HX400V which uses Bionz X processing, which looks like it might be a serious contender despite its relatively larger size, and Canon is about to announce a successor to its SX50. I have tried the Nikon P600, and see no notable changes over the 520 (and 510). The zoom speed has not improved at all, making it one of the slowest megazoom cameras.If Fuji can come up with (much) better noise processing at least matching sony, canon / nikon, and keep the hi-res evf and screen, add manual focus and speed up zoom, they will have a winner.

Reviews.Title: High quality!!
Reviews.Author: HelloDough
Reviews.Content: I got this camera as an upgrade from my small handheld canon powershoot point-and-shoot camera. And man, was it an upgrade! I was first considering a DSLR but the price was way out of my range. I got this camera after reading several reviews and jumping from camera to camera. I used it at my brother's college graduation and we sat in the way back of the Big House (google it, i was far up) but I was able to zoom all the way in to see the Commencement speakers and the orchestra kids' faces. The pictures came out very high quality. I also used the video option to record a guitar cover and i was very pleased with the quality. I was able to watch the video back in 1080p on youtube, so good stuff!

Reviews.Title: This is my 4th Fujifilm FinePix and this one is the best yet!
Reviews.Author: Sharon Barrett Kennedy "artrageous"
Reviews.Content: I have been so pleased with this brand due to its versatility.  I take a LOT of photographs and I love being able to instantly switch from the zoom setting to super macro to capture whatever catches my interest.  At first I was disappointed to see that it didn't use AA batteries, but I bought an extra Li-on battery and that way I always have a spare.  The battery life is good and I've been averaging about 300 pictures before needing to replace it.I was really surprised, too, at the quality of the video--absolutely amazing!--even though I don't use it that often.The 50x zoom allows me to get up close and personal with wildlife, and as I've experimented with the manual settings, I've been able to take some truly outstanding pictures of the moon.  (Friends have asked if I used a telescope!)If you're thinking about purchasing a much more expensive DSLR, bear in mind that you would need to buy several different expensive *lenses* to do what this one camera can do. I'm very pleased with my purchase and I will continue to recommend FinePix cameras to anyone who is looking for an affordable way to enjoy photography.

Reviews.Title: Nice bridge camera for beginners/amateurs
Reviews.Author: Elizabeth A. Gempka "Lizard"
Reviews.Content: I am going on vacation May 2014 and was looking for a camera that had more features than just a point and shoot, but I also didn't want to lug around an SLR with multiple lenses, etc. I decided on the Fujifilm and am beyond happy that I did. The camera has a viewfinder, which is a feature I was specifically looking for (I guess I'm old school like that lol) but its a bit on the temperamental side, so there's always the option to turn it off altogether. The menu is easy to navigate but I do suggest thoroughly reading the manual. The zoom feature is outstanding, but as another reviewer noted if you plan on using that feature quite a bit then its good to have extra batteries on hand. Its a great camera for someone who is just a 'beginner' or who is just looking for something a little more simple than an SLR. I also received a camera bag with this, but its WAY too small to hold anything more than the camera so I'll be buying a bigger bag to hold the extra batteries, etc. That's really my only complaint.Bottom line (from someone who's not a professional): Fun, easy to operate camera for a great price. Highly recommend.

Reviews.Title: I LOVE this camera! Great quality at an affordable price.
Reviews.Author: Bob "Mr. Bob"
Reviews.Content: I had high expectations for this camera - it has far exceeded them.I am not a professional photographer, but I wanted to get better pictures than I would get from a normal point and shoot camera. The SL1000 has met my needs.ProsThe camera is light weight. I was concerned that it would be heavy, bulky, but that is not the case.The zoom is absolutely incredible, far beyond what I expected. I took the camera with me on a short trip to Africa. We did a lion safari tour, and I was able to easily zoom in on the faces of the lions and tigers without difficulty. I never expected to get close-up portrait shots of a wild animal, but I did with this camera.One day I was outside and saw an aircraft contrail. I could not see the plane. I zoomed in with the SL-1000 and got a brilliant shot of the aircraft with the contrail behind it. If the plane was at 30,000 feet, that means it was six miles away when I took the shot! Using a tripod I have taken many pictures of the full moon and have been stunned by the high resolution: craters are easily visible and at the edge of the moon, I can clearly see the outline of mountains.The camera has a multitude of settings. I rarely take the camera out of the AUTO mode and have found the photos to be very good.I can use an HDMI cable to connect the camera to my HDTV to see the photos: they really look great on the large screen.You can use the large viewscreen on the back of the camera, or the viewfinder. Most cameras do not offer this option. I have found the viewfinder to be very helpful when shooting on an extremely sunny day. You can set the camera so that it will sense if you are using the viewfinder: when it senses you are  it will turn off the LCD screen, helping to save battery power. When you are done with the viewfinder it turns that off and turns the screen back on.The LCD screen tilts up and down. This came in very handy when I was in a crowd and had to hold the camera way above my head to take the shot. I adjusted the screen so that I could still see the shot and was able to get some good photos.It does a wonderful job, in AUTO mode, of setting depth of field. The item at the center of shot is in focus, the background is not, helping to highlight the item I am shooting. I prefer that to a photo where everything is clear.I have not used the movie option, so I cannot comment.I bought some extra batteries on Amazon and carry them with me, but have never gotten to the point of needing to replace the battery in the middle of the day.The MACRO setting is phenomenal. There are two settings, regular macro and super macro. I took some shots of some old coins - I had the camera so close that I was almost touching them. The camera was able to automatically focus, even at such a close distance, and gave me incredibly sharp photos of the coins.It has a popup flash - I've only used it a few times, it has helped a lot.Overall, I am most impressed by the amazing clarity and sharpness of the photos I have taken with this camera.ConsIt sometimes has a problem focusing in a very dimly lit area. In this case a manual focus would be a big help but it does not have one. If I took a lot of photos in dimly lit areas, this might be a big problem. However, it has rarely come up.The zoom is auto, you zoom in and out by pushing buttons. I'd like a manual control.OverallAs I said, I LOVE this camera. I have been able to take shot that I never would have imagined with any other camera. The zoom is incredible, the photos are amazingly sharp, and the camera is comfortable to hold and use. Five Stars!!

Reviews.Title: Love this camera
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: For years I've used the same 5 mp Fujifilm camera.  When I got that one that was top of the line, if that tells you how long ago it was.  After my son dropped it, and broke that camera I began looking for a replacement. After a lot research, and reading product reviews, watching video's, etc.  I decided to get this camera.  I haven't played around with all the functions, but am totally in love with this camera.  I was a little disappointed an owner's manual didn't come with the camera, but that was easily fixed by going to their sight and downloading a pdf version.  The camera comes with a basic manual.  I definitely suggest downloading the complete user manual.  At first as some other reviewers have said, it was a bit confusing and hard to get focused pictures.  After going through the Owner's manual I've gotten a better handle on what I was doing wrong.  I couldn't figure out how to work the flash until i read it either.  Now I have a great camera, with excellent zoom to take lots of pictures of my dogs, kids, the lake etc.  I recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: All my children's cameras did..???
Reviews.Author: docblade
Reviews.Content: Don't buy camera if you want to play your video on a TV with sound. This camera has an audio format that is not recognized on a TV.. All cameras I have owned did. All my children's cameras did..???

Reviews.Title: Great camera for the money
Reviews.Author: S. Foster
Reviews.Content: This camera is lightweight and easy to handle. While traveling, it gives you a lot of versatility with such an incredible zoom that other photographers are envious. The controls are very user friendly and maneuvering the various functions is straight forward and not confusing at all. I'm glad that I shopped and compared cameras because I absolutely love this Fujifilm!

Reviews.Title: awesome camera!!
Reviews.Author: Sandidee
Reviews.Content: This camera is awesome! I was a little worried about battery life after reading the reviews but have not had a problem with it dying too quick .. and it takes awesome pictures! Very nice and would totally recommend it to anyone.

Reviews.Title: Excellent product! images clear, vibrant, accurate! zoom apperciated. Great feel to the camera. Reviews helped me decide.
Reviews.Author: FB from Ann Arbor, Mi "outdoor adventurer"
Reviews.Content: First the product feels very good in the hands. Solid, well built but not extra heavy.  Macro, super macro, excellent photographs. Doesn't take an inordinately amount of time to master almost all features. Buy extra batteries and an extra 64Gb card and you'll spend next winter creating fantastic slide shows and presentations with crisp clear photos and enjoyable video. Great choice!

Reviews.Title: Great Deal for the price.
Reviews.Author: M. Kadinger
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera because I'm not interested in a true DSLR. But I wanted a bridge camera that allowed me to experiment a bit. I was not disappointed. It's a good camera for the price, and a great entry level camera for those who may want a DSLR in the future. Overall I am satisfied. But the one thing that irritated the hell out of me was the lens cap. Not a huge thing for sure, but sometimes it's the little things that count. Whoever designed that lens cap needs to be horsewhipped. It is one of those little things that you have to deal with every time you use the camera. And every single time you are forced to deal with that lens cap you will get irritated. I don't like to get irritated. Does anyone know if some company is selling an aftermarket lens cap that works? If so, please me know. I actually destroyed that lens cap that comes with this otherwise great camera. I feel better now, but I still need a lens cap.

Reviews.Title: A Camera for all Reasons!
Reviews.Author: Doug Charmley
