Reviews.Content: You name it and this little honey packs a wallop and has the right equipment to meet the many needs that are, and are not, found in the larger, bulky expensive, harder to manage well known DSLR Camera's that we know about and are used today! Where can you get 1200 lens that can double right on the same enclosed devise/equipment like is in this well accomplished Fuji FinPix SL1000 digital camera. We now have the "speed", focus,  vast lens range and all the other bells & whistles that are used, and found on, both a point and shoot and the high end DSLR's. Folks you really cant go wrong here even the price is amazing for the huge amount of "Equipment" you get in this packed little and amazing set of photo taking device/equipment. Just look around, as I and many others have, and seeee for your selves!The one concern, and problem that they could have and NEED to address is that the power needed to function this little power packed camera is that is should have came with a Better, longer lasting, higher powered battery supply. The 1700mAh  battery is not near enough for the use of the "huge zoom" lens factors, fast focus features, and the on off power usage . I recommend getting one-two more batteries for the customer; and I recommend Fuji FinePix Camera Design engineers "try" looking into their "Battery designs" for an upgrade, modification and a "Reasonable Power Increase Factor"(RPIF) of at least, and up to, and around 22000mAh to 2500mAh for "PROPER & NEED AVERAGE BATTERY USES" on this camera, Fujifilm FinePix SL1000 16.2MP Digital Camera!!!Product DescriptionThe Fuji FinePix SL1000 Digital Camera features a 16 megapixel 1/2.3" backside-illuminated CMOS sensor that is able to produce high quality imagery with notable low-light sensitivity. High speed performance is afforded throughout the system, enabling fast continuous shooting up to 10 full resolution frames per second and an auto focusing speed of 0.2 second. Full HD 1080i video capabilities are also supported at a frame rate of 60fps. An incredibly long 50x optical zoom lens is also built into the SL1000's design, giving a 35mm-equivalent focal length range of 24-1200mm. This range can be effectively doubled through the use of Intelligent Digital Zoom, and an optical image stabilization system benefits shooting at such magnifications by reducing the appearance of camera shake. Both a rear LCD monitor and electronic viewfinder are available for monitoring and image review, and both have a high 920k-dot resolution for clear image viewing.

Reviews.Title: SL 1000
Reviews.Author: Brenda
Reviews.Content: I have been shooting Professionally for over 25 years, the SL 1000 makes taking pictures Easy and Fun. I have a SL 8400 and a Cannon too.  I use to use a Fuji 901 which I would put up against any Nikon or Cannon, it was way ahead of it's time. The Varsitilly of the Sl 1000 is great, no need to carry Bulky lenses, you've got it all in one.

Reviews.Title: Great camera!!!
Reviews.Author: Poolnrd
Reviews.Content: I am in Costa Rica as I write this. Still learning all of the features this camera has to offer but I am very happy with the results of those pictures I have taken. I have pictures of birds, dozens of iguanas and coatis and a hundred or so pictures of the Westin resort and the beach. Tomorrow we travel down the river where I hope to get pictures of the monkeys, crocodiles and snakes. I'd recommend this camera to all beginner or intermediate photographer. You won't get the quality pics like those from a $1000 Canon but the pictures are certainly acceptable to me. The camera is easy to use and carry and you don't have worry about changing lenses.

Reviews.Title: The SL-1000 is just a great bridge camera!
Reviews.Author: Timothy J. Schrader
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera for novice to advance amateur.  It is part point & shoot, and part DSLR.  The controls are laid out nice and easy to use. The big owners manual is easy to read and reference.  I really enjoy taking pictures with this camera. Plus, I think Fujifilm has the best web support for their camera's and customers. Web pages are easy to use and find what you are looking for.

Reviews.Title: Excellent
Reviews.Author: Jairo M.
Reviews.Content: is better than I expected. probe took him to the moon picture and details of the relief of the moon is excellent. still learning to use all its features. practically is a professional camera.

Reviews.Title: Another great camera from Fuji
Reviews.Author: J.L.H
Reviews.Content: I'm an avid amateur photographer who spends most of my free time in my kayak.  I always take a camera because you never know when nature will bless you with an opportunity.  I have had the 18x, 30x and now the Sl1000 50x and have been extremely pleased with quality in all these Fuji cameras.  The Sl1000 is truly an amazing camera with a zoom equivalent to a 1200mm SLR lens.  The cost is reasonable and try and get something comparable for the price and quality. You won't find it.  Aces all around Fuji. Thanks.

Reviews.Title: Good quality in a money saving package
Reviews.Author: Scott Anderson "Sharpsburg"
Reviews.Content: I purchased this as a go between for my heavy SLR Digital Canon and a lesser quality video camera picked up off the shelf at Wal-Mart.  I was looking for a good quality build, great zoom lens, easy to use features and a quality name brand.  I've found some of the that with this system.  In fact some of the first pictures taken with the camera have been my favorite and are now my home page on my iPad.  I can list the Pros and Cons I see so far.Pros:50x wide angle zoom lensElectronic viewfinderManual controlsHot shoe for external flashRAW modeVery good image quality, inside and outExcellent 1080i HD video qualityFast focusing and refresh time between shotsVery good battery life.Great valueNot very heavyGreat zoom feature on lens and camera bodyTilting 3.0-inch TFT color LCD monitorCons:Small 1/2.3-inch CMOS Image Sensor.Image noise is noticeable above ISO 100.No noise reduction settings.Proprietary battery, no AA or AAA abilityI'm more than likely going to return the camera however due to the high noise issues in the images.  I've tried to compensate but it's not working out, so I will be looking into a Nikon or Canon to fill the requirements.  More to update as I progress through the next several days of picture taking.Update:8/19/2013The pictures I've been taking were at a lower setting, once I reset the camera to the correct settings the noise has really dropped off and the pictures have come out fantastic.  Several were printed up on 8x10 and 11x14 photo paper without beautiful results.  I've bumped up the review to 4 stars and I am really enjoying the camera!Update:1/12/2014Setting were pictures size and the images have been much improved.  Fuji does a nice job in mid range cameras, and I look forward to future demos from the company to showcase their ability.

Reviews.Title: I like it but....
Reviews.Author: Phillip Dacus "Meeds Met"
Reviews.Content: I do like the camera. It seems to take good pictures. It has a ton of buttons that I will probably never use. The main reason I got it was for the zoom and the shutter speed and continuous pics. I can push a button, make 1 more selection then with the press of the shutter button, take many many pics at the same time. So its easy to get lots of shots as something moves and get just the right pic. I love this.My last camera was sooo slow, that I would press the button to take a pic, but by the time the shutter actually closed to take a pic, the subject had already moved. It was terrible.The thing that is driving me nuts though is that I cant get the pics out of the camera. With other cameras. I could just plug the USB into a computer, windows would pop up something asking to import the pics and that was it. Sure Easy.With this, I plugged the USB cable into a Mac and then a PC. Nothing. I even tried loading their software into both the Mac and the PC. Still nothing. I searched the manual, but found nothing. At this point, Im thinking that the camera is defective. Surely the manufacturer would not make it this hard to do something this simple.The pics are all stored, I hope, on the card I bought. So I am hoping that I can find an easy way to get the pics off the card. If anyone has any suggestions on how to do this, please let me know.Phillip

Reviews.Title: Superb high-end point & shoot camera, you are mobile when on the go
Reviews.Author: Paramananda
Reviews.Content: The optical zooming quality is good. If I use a DSLR, I need to carry separate lenses but Fuji S1000 serves the purpose of both long range and macro level photography. With this camera, I can groom myself further and equip myself. Cost wise, it is good 'value of money'.The negative elements:You see some noise in the picture quality (whether it was clicked using zoom or not). Moreover, hand shaking control is not good enough...so it demands a greater level of patience :-) , however I'm fine with it. Last point I would like to mention is that sometimes while doing night photography, you feel too much of light in the shutter box (more than required....I know it can be adjusted to some extent but I'm talking about the auto mode :-) )Overall, I'm happy with this camera and it will be my best friend for at least 1 year or two :-)

Reviews.Title: Good camera for aspiring photographers
Reviews.Author: Michael Casey
Reviews.Content: Easy to use, but macro setting tends to white out on some macro shots or blur.  Could be something I'm doing wrong.  Otherwise I love the camera and will be taking it with me on PCT hike for several months.

Reviews.Title: Great Super Zoom Camera
Reviews.Author: kpf
Reviews.Content: When I decided to buy a 50x camera, I researched the three brands that were available at the time.  Really couldn't make a decision by the reviews, as they all had both good and not so good reviews.  I decided to go with the less expensive model, and I couldn't be happier!  I bought the camera to use mostly at concerts, as my Olympus 35x had difficulty focusing on moving subjects amid flashing lights.  Took this camera to a recent show and got some amazing photos from 25 rows back - you could actually see the color of the artist's eyes!  Also took a picture of the "supermoon" with no tripod, and it turned out beautifully - able to see all of the craters, etc.  Definitely recommend to anyone looking to save a few dollars over the Canon and Sony cameras - this speaks volumes from a former Sony fan!

Reviews.Title: Mixed bag but great zoom
Reviews.Author: Grimmy "Grimmy"
Reviews.Content: First, the good. 50X zoom. RAW recording. Multiple-pic modes (flash on/off, HDR, zoom bracketing, best frame, etc.). Viewfinder. Somewhat-tilting 920k-dot screen. 10-shot burst mode. Movie editing mode. Motion panorama. Super slow-motion filming. Manual controls. Hot shoe, which lets you attach external flashes.The zoom is amazing, if sometimes iffy indoors - it sometimes had trouble focusing on objects within a room. Outdoors, much better, although you may still get some blur at max zoom. Using the zoom a lot will use up the battery more, though.RAW is there if you want to play around with it, but for non-DSLR owners, it's probably going to be unused, unless you want to get familiar with RAW editing.The multiple-pic modes are useful, but not easy to get to - you have to switch modes and pick the one you want unless it's already assigned. You could use the one Fn button for something (ISO, image size/quality, white balance, etc.), but it may not have the function you want.The viewfinder lets you hold the camera steadier. It has a sensor turns the LCD on and off when you use it. However, you may find yourself triggering it by mistake.The screen tilts up and down only, to a limited degree, although still useful.Slow-mo uses a smaller screen size, understandably. You can get some really nifty stuff here. Zoom works during video recording, although you'll hear the motor.Nice, rubberized feel.In auto mode, it tends to overexpose quite a bit. This is probably the most annoying aspect of this camera.Noise starts at ISO 200, somewhat grainy at 800, soft pics at 1600 and up. Low-light produced less-than-sharp pictures. Generally good pictures in normal conditions, but if you're picky you may notice pink/purple fringing at the edges.Aperture priority is limited to three choices, for whatever reason.The spring-loaded power switch may trip you up sometimes and keep you from getting that fast startup.To be fair, I was expecting much better performance from their advertising, so I could have set too high a bar. But the zoom is a huge advantage, the pictures are usually good enough, and the other features such as burst mode and HDR will help take better pictures. A spare battery is a must, though.

Reviews.Title: A huge number of features for this price point
Reviews.Author: E. Swope
Reviews.Content: I have really been enjoying using the Fujifilm SL1000, and am overall very impressed with its flexibility, number of features, and most importantly, image quality.  Some months back I was shopping for a DSLR for my daughter's birthday.  As I reviewed the options I became more aware of how many improvements had been introduced since I last upgraded my camera.  Suddenly I found myself shopping for 2 cameras.  Hers was actually the easier, as she is a fairly accomplished photographer, knows what she wants and needs and has a lot of lenses from a certain company.  For myself, the decision was a lot more difficult as I wanted fine image quality (primarily for shooting art glass) and a good zoom for my son's band performances, high sensitivity for night photos, and to eliminate the need for flash in the glass photos.  In other words, I was looking for a good all-around camera, without breaking the bank.  After reading dozens, maybe even hundreds of reviews, I decided that a bridge camera would be a good choice but found it a challenge to balance quality, features and my price point.  For the past 10 years or so I have been using Panasonic Lumix cameras and have been very happy with the quality (both build and image) as well as the flexibility (long zoom, small package).  To be truthful, it was the introduction of their FZ200 which made me feel like my old camera was sorely lacking.  I set the FZ200 and it's cousin the Leica V-Lux as the "holy grail" attempting to match features and quality within my price bracket (no easy task).  Reviewing the options, several popular cameras which shared most of the features were in my range,but I really wasn't satisfied with image quality.  I ultimately purchased an Olympus Pen micro 2/3 for the image quality and the ability to use my old Minolta lenses.  That, however, was a fairly big disappointment (if interested, that review is here http://www.amazon.com/Olympus-Thirds-Interchangeable-Digital-14-42mm/product-reviews/B004L9IXWI/ref=cm_cr_dp_synop?ie=UTF8&showViewpoints;=0&sortBy;=bySubmissionDateDescending#R2YXXZAS08PQNH ). Back to the hunt.  I considered the Fujifilm FinePix HS50EXR 16 MP Digital Camera with 3-Inch LCD (Black) but nixed it because of the manual zoom.  To cut to the chase, the SL1000 builds on the features of the HS50 adding a 50x zoom lens and very bright optics (F2.9-5.6), very nice in a lens this size, achieving ISO sensitivity to 12800. It has a CMOS sensor and optical image stabilization, which produces a  nice image quality, even at maximum zoom (see sample photos).  The articulating screen and electronic viewfinder (a rarity in bridge cameras in this range) providing excellent options for composing shots in a variety of lighting conditions.  Both start-up and recovery are fast, so I do not have to worry about losing shots as I did with the Pen...which brings me to another favorite feature which I did not initially consider: moving object tracking.  Since I did not get this with sports photography in mind, and my kids are at an age where I can get them to stay still, it was not a high priority, BUT combined with image stabilization makes for some nice sharp pictures, compensating nicely for shake, wind or movement which can blur pictures, problems often accentuated in a large zoom.  That said, I could recommend this as a good camera for people with toddlers, pets, or sports fans.  It gets nice action shots.The SL1000  offers a full range of options for manual control, as well as auto focus and the ability to effectively use it as a point & shoot.  Unlike many cameras in this price range it provides the option of shooting Raw.  Several creative filters are available, as well as the ability to do panorama stitch in-camera (and stitch video as well).  The only thing which took this camera down a notch in my eyes is that the color reproduction was not as accurate as on 2 other cameras I compared it to (a Lumix travel zoom and PEN micro 4/3).  Granted this is not comparing apples with apples, however, in terms of sharpness, depth, overall quality, it compared nicely, producing better pictures than the other 2 in most circumstances!  The colors on the Fuji were just a little hot, popped too much, or seemed unnatural on some shots (most evident on pink & red flowers).  There is still some temptation on my part to give this 5 stars taking price into account, as in truth comparing it to a camera which costs 3x as much or is a completely different format is not really fair.The bottom line is that it shoots nice crisp pictures, provides a huge amount of flexibility and has a good solid build at a very reasonable price point.  It's a combination which is tough to match.

Reviews.Title: Good feature rich camera for the price
Reviews.Author: Patrick Holt "txdragon"
Reviews.Content: I have the previous version of the camera, and its nice to see that they listened to some suggestions for the new version.  The main things that stand out to me are:1. Ability to save your photos in Raw Format - this is a great feature, that there is no excuse not to include.2. Lens optic have improved, pictures are much sharper3. Better low light capability with less noise at higher ISO but not on par with bigger sensor camera's but that's to be expected.4. If your not into shooting raw, the JPG processing engine does a nice job as well.5. Better construction and control layout6. Manual control -sort of- including aperture and shutter speed.Like the last version it has super zoom.  Now this is a great thing and kind of the main feature of the camera. But keep in mind, the more you zoom the more camera shake gets magnified.  You you try zoom all the way and go hand held, you probably will have some soft or blurry pictures if the subject is close up.Overall for the price this is very versatile and good camera that I would consider prosumer.

Reviews.Title: loads of cool features, meh in low/med light
Reviews.Author: Laura B
Reviews.Content: 3.5 stars (I'm rounding up to 4 because I think I am comparing too much to a DSLR.)I have been wanting to get a mid-range camera. I have a couple of older point-n-shoot cameras and a DSLR.  I wanted something that was better than the smaller cameras, but not as complicated as a DSLR.  This seems like the perfect choice.  For most things I really, really like this camera.  It has a couple of things I don't like.So, let's start with all the cool features.The video capability on this thing is AMAZING!  There are so options from FULL HD to high speed filming!  I'm not sure how often I will use the HS filming, but it sure was funny to watch my 5.5 month old jumping in his jumperoo in slow motion.  The HD is beautiful quality.  I was amazed how awesome it looks on my computer.  And to record?  Just push the little red dot button--no need to change modes (a pain and you can easily miss something if you are changing modes to go from still to video).There are tons of different setting options.  You can do full manual, aperture priority, shutter priority, Auto, and Auto select (it detects the type of photo for you).  You can essentially act like you have a DSLR (without lens options) or a point-n-shoot.The lens is super HUGE.  I know all the reviews mention this, but it is important to mention.  This thing goes from wide-angle to super close-up.  WOW.  Just WOW.Now, for what I think could be improved.Low-light/medium-light shots are noisy.  When I shoot photos indoors during the day with seemingly plenty of light, the pictures still look grainy.  Plus, they seem a little overexposed and washed out.  There are no vibrate colors at all.  I admit that I don't care to use the flash much, so if I did use the flash it looks better, but it is obvious I used the flash.  Plus, things are still a little overexposed.  I tried changing different settings for this (ISO, shutter, or aperture priority), but nothing seemed to work.  Plus, since I was photographing my kids (5.5-month twins and a 2-year-old), I got a lot of blur.  Leading me to my next nit...The focus is just ok.  I really like my DSLR with a grid of focus points I can choose from.  Here, I am given a few choices, but I cannot pick the specific focus point (outside of tricks of focusing and then moving the camera).  You can do center, continuous, tracking, or multiple.  I was trying to take pictures of my twins, so I had it on multiple, but it kept focusing behind them, so they ended up blurry compared to an in-focus background.Overall, this is a cool camera that does so much for its price-point.  I think it would be great for someone thinking about upgrading to a DSLR, but not wanting to spend that much money on lenses or accessories.  Just be mindful that it is better for outdoor photos and not indoor portraits (unless you like using a flash, which I prefer to use natural light).  I don't recommend this for someone wanting to take pictures of their kids or just for family pictures around the house.

Reviews.Content: Granted the only thing I have really used the camera to take photos of, are sports cars moving at a fairly high speed, I had to use multi-shot, but i had a few moments where it was on single mode, but the settings were perfect for some lucky shots that turned out to be the best I had of the day.Great camera, certainly recommend to anyone looking for a "bridge" camera, and I highly recommend learning about using the functions of the aperture, and shutter speed, as using the auto settings will not make you improve your skill (if you are looking to improve anyway).Ridiculous zoom range, anything over 100 meters is easily focused in on by this camera.I'm still learning the ropes with this camera, and the settings beyond the preset ones.

Reviews.Author: C. Hammaker

He had never used the camera before and was able to take great shots of the red moon.I use the camera mainly for videoing my son's wrestling matches.  The camera takes excellent videos at 60 fps, which makes it easy to view in slow motion for review with his coach. Reviews.Title: Super "FUN" Camera, beautiful pictures.
Reviews.Author: R. Neese
Reviews.Content: I've owned this camera for over 6 months and have shot hundreds of pictures with it.  I love it.  This is the most fun camera that I have ever owned.  Pictures are beautiful.  The many modes of operation and HD video make it super versatile and allow you to be creative.  It can even shoot Slow-motion video as well as 3D pix.For me, the 50x zoom lens is it's best feature.  (That's equivalent to a 1200mm lens on a 35mm camera.)  I've taken pictures of the moon with it that show more detail than my astronomical telescope does.  I've also focused in on wildlife 100 yards away that appear in the viewfinder, to be right in front of me.  An equivalent Cannon telescopic lens would cost about $17,000.  For real.  Look it up.  (Of course the Cannon lens would be much superior in quality.)I'm very satisfied with the pictures taken by this camera.What I don't like about it is that the battery compartment cover feels flimsy and I need to be very careful when opening it to extract the battery or SD memory card.  Also don't like that the lens cover sometimes pops off easily and also that no filters or lens hood can be mounted.I'd definitely recommend this camera if you want to explore photography and have fun at a very reasonable price.

Reviews.Author: Scott_G

Reviews.Content: There are some aspects that I loved about this camera, but others that came up short.Pros:-Amazing zoom in a reasonably small package-Has many DSLR features without being a DSLR camera-Excellent grip, which is much better than many camaras I have tried in the past, including several DSLRs-Easy to use, if you are looking for a camera that can do some nifty things without having to take a photography course to get it done, this camera might be what you wantCons:-Even though the zoom is truly amazing, it is extremely hard to get crisp pictures inside when using the zoom setting near its max.-The on-off button is awkward to say the least, not sure who came up with that idea-The battery died on me after a month, I fully charged it before the first use but I already noticed that it took longer than what the manual said it should take to charge. Reviews.Title: DSLRish but not a DSLR replacement
Reviews.Author: Kanishk Rastogi "Freelenser"
Reviews.Content: Adding to the comments from other reviewers- 50 X Zoom and 16 MP are really fantastic.- Camera form and fit is very good and Fuji did a very good job with the layout like main dial, buttons, etc to provide an ease of use.- Picture quality is good in auto mode and Super Auto mode which can continuously change the settings automatically as you move around the camera in a scene.- Low light capability is decently good. Not at DSLR level like with the wide aperture lenses, but lot better than the standard point-n-shoot.- Size is definitely not too small. Under most conditions you will need a belt-pack at least. It may fit in a jacket pocket in winters.- A/S/M mode shooting is not very convenient and easy to go with. However, I have 2 other DSLRs and if I am in a situation where I really need that perfect shot with all the right settings, I will go with a DSLR. For most other daily purposes, this one will work fine.- Battery life is on the lower side which surprised me a little, but its not really a dealbreaker if you are not one of those "photography day trips" kind of people.- At very high zooms, the pictures can be blurred or shaky, so it will depend on the user to get the best use out of this. I think it works well upto 40X.- Screen tilt option is really very useful, especially if you trying to get an infant to look at the camera .- One issue which I have noticed is that the colors are not always consistent under the same set of lighting. For example, in our living room the lighting sources are always same but still I notice the color rendering to be different at times. I will not expect this in a camera in 300 price range.Overall, this is nice camera if you are debating whether to buy a DSLR. It has several of those features with a good image quality, but I recommend to look for the right deal!

Reviews.Title: Fujifilm camera
Reviews.Author: C Bear "biker"
Reviews.Content: As much as I wanted to give this camera 5 stars, there were enough little things about it that didn't warrant it. The on/off switch is tricky and can make you try more than once to start the camera up. When finally engaged, start up is fast but still slower than the Canon Powershot SX40 and SX50. If you take burst frames at the maximum file size, it will stop to save the frames taken causing a loss of action. Use a lower size option if quality isn't an issue.My biggest problem with the camera is the inconsistency of photo quality under the same lighting conditions. It will over or under expose using the same aperture, speed and lighting conditions in a 2 or 3 minute time frame. I'm use to having all photos taken within a short time having similar characteristics as long as they are taken in the same conditions.The 16mp capability is great. Most photos do come out looking beautiful just fewer than I usually get with other cameras. The panorama feature is effortless and gives fantastic results without having to stitch a series of photos together at the computer. Since you don't have to reposition the camera for each shot and instead pan the vista, there is less problem with cloud and shadow movement.An unthinkable oversite by Fuji is not being able to attach filters for protection of the lens and other uses. The greatest plus is the zooming capability. It truly does bring the smallest object up close. Although I have gotten good photos hand-holding the camera at maximum zoom, do use a tripod. It improves your chances of a great shot each time and is less tiresome than straining to hold the camera steady.  Carry a tripod and use it. You'll be glad you did.Download a user's manual if you didn't get one with the camera. There are a lot of options you would be unaware of without it.

Reviews.Title: Fujifilm FinePix SL1000
Reviews.Author: L. Steiner
Reviews.Content: First of all,  this camera is big, please see the picture I posted of it next to my 18x zoom camera, although being big is not always a bad thing. It's easy to hold and the separation between the buttons is good. The barrel of the lens makes a steady platform to hold the camera and surprise, there's a second zoom control on the side of the lens so you can zoom while keeping your trigger finger on the button. The surprises continue with the presets and programs, things you didn't even know you needed! For example, Motion Panorama 360- hold the shoot button down and turn in a circle and you get a 360 degree view. Check out the product description for the other features and you'll still probably be surprised by a feature when you get it. The rear display adjusts to perpendicular when viewing down while shooting low and to about 45 degrees down to view when holding the camera over your head. The Goldfinch picture I uploaded was taken with moderate zoom at 20 feet and no tripod, and the Tiger Lily was taken on Super Macro.

Or spend $200 more and get the X20 fuji.

Reviews.Title: King of the ultrazooms - UPDATED - camera broken after two weeks.
Reviews.Author: ScOObydoo
Reviews.Content: UPDATED REVIEW: The camera stopped working after about two weeks, any time I press the shutter, it turns off. To make matters worse, Fujifilm has has the camera for a month, and still doesn't have an ETA on the repair time.UPDATE 2: Now almost two months later, and the camera is still with the repair center "waiting on parts". Disgraceful compamny.Crikey - what an overlooked and awesome camera this is. Amazing how a once mega brand like Fuji can barely even find shelf space at the local electronics store when they make brilliant cameras like this. Lets start with the obvious - that lens! When fully extended, it just looks plain silly, but the range is fan-tas-tic! Sitting on a patio, I spotted something tiny, pulled out the camera and zoomed all the way into the point where my eyes could barely even see that far.Photos come out almost perfect - at full length, you obviously lose a lot of light, so don't expect to use it in anything other than daylight, but on auto the results are a step above most P&S;'s in this price range.Add things like a great sensor (for the price), hotshoe, viewfinder (with eye-sensor), tilting screen, support for RAW, 10FPS and even 60FPS hd movies and you have a true winner. This thing even beats the similar Nikon and Canon products hands-down.Downsides - it is big - DSLR big, the lens at full length feels "wobbly" and there is no remote/mic input. But at $329, this thing can not be beat.

Reviews.Title: Fuji sl1000 Zoom vs Canon sx 50 hs Zoom
Reviews.Author: Marcus W
Reviews.Content: I am just a "point and shooter" when it comes to these two cameras. I dont know the technical stuff about the cameras, but heres what i have experienced with both the "Fuji sl1000" and the "Canon sx50 hs". I would rather do a video, but it will take longer than 10mins.Trust me i already tried to talk about 1 camera in under 10 mins, and its very hard to do.Which is probably why nobody posted a video.  First of all the Fuji camera came with everything you need to operate the camera and the link cable so that one could upload the photos to the internet. The Canon camera didnt come with a "basic instruction manual". It came with a disk.  The fuji came with a disk also but it came with a "paper manual" as well. The Canon didnt even come with a link cable.The Fuji Camera is cheaper than the Canon, but came with more. Yay for Fuji! :DFuji is more difficult to navigate than Canon. On the outside, Canon has more options(buttons) than the Fuji.  Canon comes out of the box ready to use. When you turn the Canon on, all you do is point, Zooooooom and shoot. You will get the 200x(optical+digital), yes i said 200x zoom right out of the box. But not the Fuji. Fuji you will get only the 50x right out of the box. Which almost made me give the fuji a "not so good" review.  Yes you can get the 200x zoom with the Fuji, in order to do so you must "Press the Playback (button w triangle inside of square)Button, Press Left on the FN(function dial), then press Down to select the settings option,  Press Right, then scroll down to "INTELLIGENT DIGITAL ZOOM", then turn it on. After that, back out then press menu button, scroll down to "INSTANT ZOOM" then select  2.0x, and after you do that, back out and now you have 200x zoom. This formula equals (50xoptical + 50xdigital= 100x then 100x times 2.0x = 200x) NOTE : when you turn on Instant Zoom, you decrease the screen view to a little box. AND you must turn on INSTANT DIGITAL ZOOM everytime you cut the camera off. There may be away to prevent that like by using the custom feature.  When the "Canon" zooms to its max zoom, it does so smoothly, while focusing alot better than the "Fuji", and maintains focus alot better than the "Fuji" also. When zooming with the "Fuji", the Fuji is noticeably louder than the Canon.  According to the LCD screen on the camera, Canons photos look better than the Fuji photos. But i wont judge these two by the LCD screen. Again The Canons photos via LCD screen looks better than the Fuji.  I like both cameras and both camera zooms, i like the ease of use of the zoom with canon, better. so therefore i choose the canon over the fuji when it comes to the zoom, and clarity.  Note : Canon is a 12 megapixal and Fuji is a 16 megapixel camera.  Not sure how they effect the zoom.  That concludes my experience and opinion of these two superzoom cameras, super zooms :D  Oh yea i have seen ppl say that theres no way to cut off the automatic electric view finder on the Fuji. Well, they are wrong. You can do such by pressing the EVF button one time for off, another press to move the view to EVF, another press to turn automatic EVF off.Update: I was just playing with the ADV mode and 3D mode on the Fuji, this Camera is soo nice i will post a picture or few from ADV mode.
